tagline: SDL on the TI-Nspire, oh boy!
name: nSDL
body:
### So what's this nSDL thing about?

nSDL is the port of SDL to the [TI-Nspire](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/TI-Nspire_series) calculators. If you're unsure what SDL is, here's a short summary from the [official website](http://www.libsdl.org/):

>Simple DirectMedia Layer is a cross-platform multimedia library designed to provide low level access to audio, keyboard, mouse, joystick, 3D hardware via OpenGL, and 2D video framebuffer. It is used by MPEG playback software, emulators, and many popular games, including the award winning Linux port of "Civilization: Call To Power."

In much more general terms, nSDL makes game development on the TI-Nspire a lot easier (although it is not restricted for games only). It also allows computer programs that use SDL (some examples [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_games_using_SDL) and [here](http://www.libsdl.org/games.php?order=name&category=-1&completed=0&os=-1&match_name=&perpage=-1)) to be ported on the said calculator.

### Alrighty then, what now?

If you're new to TI-Nspire development and/or want to know how to easily set up your Ndless/SDL environment, move on to the [how-to guide](https://github.com/Hoffa/nSDL/wiki/How-to-guide). Once you're ready, you might want to take a look at the [TI-Nspire game programming introduction](https://github.com/Hoffa/nSDL/wiki/Starting-game-programming-on-the-TI-Nspire).

There might also be some useful pieces of information on the [wiki](https://github.com/Hoffa/nSDL/wiki), so make sure to check it out.
